hints.content: Start by understanding the operation you need to perform. You must select an element from the array, remove it, and add a new element that is one greater than the selected element. This operation will increase your score by the value of the selected element.
Consider how many times you need to perform this operation. You need to do it exactly k times. Think about which elements in the array will yield the highest score when selected.
A good strategy is to always select the current maximum element from the array. This is because selecting the highest number will maximize your score for that operation.
After selecting an element, remember to update the array by removing the selected element and adding the new element (m + 1). This means your array will change after each operation.
Think about how to efficiently find the maximum element in the array. You might want to use a data structure that allows for quick access to the maximum value, such as a max-heap.
As you perform the k operations, keep a running total of your score. Each time you select the maximum element, add its value to your score before updating the array.
Consider edge cases, such as when k is equal to the length of the array. In this case, you will be selecting all elements, so think about how that might affect your score.
When you select the maximum element, ensure that you are correctly updating the array. This is crucial because the next maximum element may change after each operation.
If there are multiple elements with the same maximum value, you can choose any of them. However, remember that after you select one, the next maximum might be different.
Finally, after performing all k operations, make sure to return the total score you have accumulated. This should be the sum of all the selected elements during the k operations.

questionNotes: The operations must be performed exactly k times.
If multiple maximum elements exist, any can be chosen.
